title: 110_hr3210
content: The Act titled "Wounded Warriors Expansion of Care Act of 2007" provides medical care and benefits for members and former members of the Armed Forces with severe injuries or illnesses. The "Wounded Warriors Expansion of Care Act of 2007" entitles covered members and former members of the Armed Forces with severe injuries or illnesses to medical and dental care in uniformed services facilities or through authorized civilian health care providers for conditions like traumatic brain injury and post-traumatic stress disorder. Covered members and former members of the Armed Forces with severe injuries or illnesses are entitled to medical and dental care for conditions like traumatic brain injury and post-traumatic stress disorder. This care is provided in uniformed services facilities or through authorized civilian health care providers. Members or former members with injuries or illnesses incurred or aggravated between October 7, 2001, and the date of the Act's enactment are entitled to care for a three-year period from the date of enactment. No compensation is payable for any period before the enactment of the Act. Members or former members of the Armed Forces with severe injuries or illnesses are entitled to medical and dental care for conditions like traumatic brain injury and post-traumatic stress disorder. The period of care authorized may be extended for up to two years to ensure maximum recovery and rehabilitation. The Secretary of Defense oversees integrated care management. The Secretary of Defense oversees integrated care management for members with severe injuries or illnesses, providing medical and dental care with waivers of limitations to maximize care. The Secretary of Defense may provide medical and dental care with waivers to ensure maximum recovery and rehabilitation for members or former members of the Armed Forces. This provision does not affect eligibility for veterans benefits, and the care under this subsection will not be provided after December 31, 2012. Members of the Armed Forces with severe injuries or illnesses are entitled to rehabilitation and vocational benefits from the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to aid in their recovery and rehabilitation. This benefit does not include compensation and is effective as of the date of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Defense shall reimburse the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for benefits provided to covered members of the Armed Forces for medical care and related travel expenses. The military department may reimburse covered members of the Armed Forces and former members with severe injuries or illnesses for medical expenses incurred during required medical care. Covered expenses include health care services and travel expenses for non-medical attendants. The military department may reimburse members of the Armed Forces and former members for medical expenses during required medical care, including health care services and travel expenses for non-medical attendants appointed by a competent medical authority. The amount of reimbursement is determined by regulations prescribed by the Secretary of Defense. In this section, "severe injury or illness" is defined as a serious injury or illness with a disability rating of 30 percent or higher. The Act defines "covered member of the armed forces" as a member undergoing medical treatment for a serious injury or illness, and "family member" as defined in section 411h(b) of title 37, United States Code. The term "medical hold or medical holdover status" refers to the status of a member of the Armed Forces receiving medical care at a military hospital or separated from their unit for health care needs. In the context of the Armed Forces, "injury or illness" refers to a condition incurred in the line of duty that may make a member unfit for their military responsibilities.
